Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Analysis and Measures of Risks in Modern Electric Energy Portfolio and Its Impacts on Power System Reliability: Measures, Algorithms and Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objectives:

The goal of this Electric Supply Risk research is to establish scientific frameworks and to develop novel algorithms for measurement of risks in future electric energy supply and their impacts on the power system reliability. The approaches include extending the recent advances in risk analysis theory to develop efficient computational algorithms, construct output models of intermittent and variable energy resources, and apply the research outcomes to develop measures of the risks in future electric energy supply. These risk measures will be used to understand and quantify the impact of integration of large-scale uncertain generation resources on the power system reliability.

Intellectual Merit:

The intellectual merit of this project lies in its interdisciplinary research that will advance the principles, measures, algorithms and applications for understanding and quantifying the risks in the future energy supply and their impacts on the power system reliability.

Broader Impacts:

The broader impact of this project comes from the fundamental research and the technological advancement that address several key issues in defining the impact of risks from renewable energy resources. These risks directly affect the execution of the national energy policy. The broader impact is also reflected in the integrated education to address a serious nation-wide issue: severe reduction of power engineering workforce in the near future. This project will promote the participation from under-represented groups and women in power and renewable energy research. Furthermore, the proposed outreach to high school students will be helpful to increase their awareness of the benefit of renewable energy and the necessity of risk management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Project Outcome Report

 The challenges of managing the reliability of next generation electric power grid come from the increased level and variety of uncertainties in the future electric power generation portfolio. These uncertainties, including those from variable renewable energy resources, distributed energy generations, and the market activities, as well as global environmental changes did not exist previously when the theories of power system operation were developed. The underlying challenges are shaping the new normal of the power grid, with significant ramifications in the society, industries, and public policies.

 The outcomes of this research project are of fundamental interest to the management of reliability and risks in the new normal of the power grid, through which various energy resources are interconnected. With all kinds of challenges in mind, solutions to a number of pressing issues are developed to address several critical challenges such as power generation modeling for grid resilience management, integration of distributed energy resources, and transmission planning with renewables, etc., arising from control room operations to the market activities.

 Expanded from our previous theoretical analysis on control and operation of grid-connected wind turbines, a broad conceptual framework is constructed for modeling electricity power generation of various energy resources for reliability assessment at the system/grid level. We have shown theoretically that a uniform structure can be constructed to characterize different types of power generation technologies, including both conventional and renewable ones. For many reliability and risk analyses, particularly those carried out for grid level problems, appropriately constructed uniform models are very much desired, not only because they simplify the work, it also supports a rigorous theoretical assessment that may leads to more insights that might be hard to obtained otherwise. The knowledge and insights obtained from the theoretical analyses have enabled us to develop a number of practical models of generation resources with uniform structure that suitable for analyzing the nature, structure, times-scale and impact of uncertainties. These models have adopted by several electric utility companies and Regional Transmission Operators (RTOs) to address a number of long standing challenges to better cope with uncertainties and risks such as those in wide-area system restoration planning and coordination. For an example of project outcome, a conceptual model of wind turbines in wind farms was extended to the analyses of frequency dynamics during the restoration process of cold load following a large-scale blackout. Due to the simplicity, flexibility and appropriate level of accuracy of the conceptual model, we are able to provide the control room a set of fast and accurate solutions to assess the frequency stability and decision support tools to manage generation fleet with uncertain availability, coordinate the load demand, and deal with the surprises in real-time. Moreover, the outcomes of research have also been used to better described, foresee and prepare for the uncertainties and risks when making decisions on transmission expansion, generation investment, cost allocation and regulatory policies pertinent to the renewables.

 The next generation power grid will be very different cry from what we are seeing today. The scientific findings and practical solutions coming out from this research project added new values for better understanding, modeling and managing the reliability and risks in the new normal of the power grid. These values will help power system engineers to gain more knowledge and new insights to deal with uncertainties and surprises in real time and under various demanding reliability mandates. Moreover, it is conceived that the findings and solutions from this project may bridge the gap between cutting-edge advances in emerging sciences and traditional thinking of power system engineering: not only supporting new technological advances for operation of the next generation power grid, also, turning the electric power grid to be used as a real-world testing bed in basic research of a new kind of science for physics of energy interconnections. Finally, it is acknowledged that the project funding has been used to support several graduate and undergraduate students, including women and minorities, who have participated in the research.
